text: There is a very simple question that hardly anyone seems
to have asked. @@bold@@Of the things we teachers do,
which help learning and which prevent it?@@/bold@@ [...]
Once we understand that some of the things we teachers do may be helpful,
some merely useless and some downright harmful, we can begin to ask which is which.
@@bold@@But only teachers can ask such questions and use their daily work with students to test their answers.
All other kinds of research into ways of improving teaching lead mostly to expensive fads and nonsense. @@/bold@@
With the possible execution of economics, education is probably the largest field of human activity
in which there are almost no connection between theory and experience,
in which people rarely test theories to see if they
work and reject or change them if they don't
author: John Holt

text: Computer science inverts the normal.
In normal science, you're given a world,
and your job is to find out the rules.
In computer science, @@bold@@you give the computer the rules,
and it creates the world.@@/bold@@
author: Alan Kay

text: It is 100 years since John Dewey began arguing for the kind of change
that would move schools away from authoritarian classrooms
with abstract notions to environments in which @@bold@@learning is achieved through experimentation,
practice and exposure to the real world.@@/bold@@
I, for one, believe the @@bold@@computer makes Dewey’s vision far more accessible@@/bold@@ epistemologically.
It also makes it politically more likely to happen,
for where Dewey had nothing but philosophical arguments,
the present day movement for change has an army of agents.
The ultimate pressure for the change will be child power.
author: Seymour Papert

text: Talking about the problems of the world
without talking about solutions is the way to paralysis
rather than progress
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo

text: In engineering the hard part isn't solving the problems,
but deciding what problems to solve
author: Paul Graham

text: The greatest wisdom not applied to action and behavior is meaningless data
author: Peter Drucker

text: The goal of education is not to increase the amount of knowledge
but to create the possibilities for a child to invent and discover,
to create men who are capable of doing new things.
author: Jean Paiget

text: If we don't change direction soon, we'll end up where we're going.
author: Irwin Corey

text: @@bold@@Education consists either in the ability to use one's powers in a social direction, or else in ability to share in the experiences of others@@/bold@@
and thus widen the individual consiousness to that of the race.
The kind of person who should emerge from a truly liberalized education
would be prepared to learn thruoghout his life,
capable of acting in his natural and social world effectively,
and with a sense of obligation to human society , past present and future.
There was isolation of one set of  studies from one set of studies from another
and a lack of unified connections of lower, middle, and higher parts of the system.
To reach the desired end, the school has been converted into the most dehumanizing institution
that I have ever laid eyes upon, @@bold@@each child being treated as if he possessed a memory
and the facility of speech, but no individuality, no sensibilities, no soul@@/bold@@
author: Joseph Mayer Rice

text: It is our knowledge — the things we are sure of — that makes the world go wrong and keeps us from seeing and learning.
author: Lincoln Steffens

text: The function of education is to teach one to @@bold@@think intensively@@/bold@@
and to @@bold@@think critically@@/bold@@. Intelligence plus character – that is the goal of true education.
author: Martin Luther King, Jr.

text: Our school crisis is a reflection of this greater social crisis. We seem to have lost our identity.
@@bold@@Children and old people are penned up and locked away from the business of the world to a degree without precedent
- nobody talks to them anymore and without children and old people mixing in daily life
a community has no future and no past, only a continuous present.@@/bold@@ In fact, the name "community" hardly
applies to the way we interact with each other.@@bold@@ We live in networks, not communities, and everyone I know is lonely@@/bold@@
because of that. In some strange way school is a major actor in this tragedy just as it is a major actor in the widening guilt
among social classes. Using school as a sorting mechanism @@bold@@we appear to be on the way to creating a caste system@@/bold@@, complete with
untouchables who wander through subway trains begging and sleep on the streets.
author: John Taylor Gatto

text: Learning isn't a way of reaching one's potential but rather a way of developing it
author: Anders Ericsson

text: We always hope for an easy fix[...] But few things in life work this way. Instead, success requires making a hundred small steps go right
author: Atul Gawande

text: Complexity is your enemy, any fool can make something more complicated. It is hard to keep something simple
author: Richard Branson

text: Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn
author: Ben Franklin

text: What I cannot create, I do not understand
author: Richard Feynman

text: If you can't explain it simply, you don't understand it well enough
author: Albert Einstein

text: The first principle is that you must not fool yourself, and you are the easiest person to fool
author: Richard Feynman

text: People are only mean when they are threatened, and that is what our culture does. That's what our economy does
author: Mitch Albom

text: Don't be afraid to be confused. Try to stay permanently confused.
Anything is possible. Stay open, forever, so open it hurts and then open up some more until the day you die
, world without end, amen
author: Geurge Saunders

text: To become an extremist, hang around with people you agree with
author: Cass Sunstein

text: Greatness and nearsightedness are incompatible. Meaningful achievement depends on lifting one's sights and pushing towards the horizon
author: Daniel Pink

text: Better is possible. It does not take genius. It takes diligence. It takes moral clarity, it takes ingenuity.
And above all it takes a willingness to try
author: Atul Gawande

text: Better to be roughly right than percisely wrong
author: Charlie Munger

text: Every man must decide whether he will walk in the light of creative altruism or in the darkness of destructive selfishness.
author: Martin Luther King, Jr.

text: Happiness lies in the joy of achievement and the thrill of creative effort
author: Franklin D. Roosevelt

text: Any Intelligent fool can make things more complex...it takes a touch of genius
and a lot of courage to go in the opposite direction
author: Albert Einstein

text: We are what we pretend to be, so we must be careful about what we pretend to be
author: Kurt Vonnegut

text: If failure isn't an option then neither is success
author: Seth Godin

text: Our comforting conviction that the world makes sense rests on a secure foundation:
our almost unlimited ability to ignore or ignorance
author: Daniel Kahneman

text: If we teach today as we taught yesterday, we rob our children of tomorrow
author: John Dewey

text: The poor seem to be struggling from the same kinds of problems s as the rest of us, lack of information, weak beliefs and procrastination
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo

text: The only normal people are the ones you don't know very well.
author: Alfred Adler

text: A glorious failure is better than a petty success
author: Alfred Adler

text: You keep kicking versions out the door, making them better. Any individual product is less important than the basic idea. If a beta turns people off, you put out a beta that turns them back on
author: Marc Andreessen

text: The greats weren't great because at birth they could paint, the greats we're great because they paint a lot
author: Macklemore

text: By themselves, character and integrity do not accomplish anything. But their absence faults everything else.
author: Peter Drucker

text: We do not need magic to transform our world. We carry all the power we need inside ourselves already.
We have the power to imagine better
author: J.K. Rowling

text: The peculiar way in which @@italic@@expectations about what education is supposed
to deliver@@/italic@@ distort what parents demand, what both public and private schools.
To reach the desired end, the school has been converted into the most dehumanizing institution
and what children achieve--and @@bold@@the colossal waste that ensues@@/bold@@
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo

text: At the societal level, the pattern of beliefs and behavior means that most
school systems are both unfair and wasteful. The children of the rich go to schools
that not only teach more and teach better, but where they are treated with compassion and helped
to reach their true potential. The poor end up in schools that make it very clear quite early on
that they are not wanted unless they show some exceptional gifts, and they are in effect expected
to suffer in silence until they drop out
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo

text: A combination of unrealistic goals, unnecessarily pessimistic expectations
, and wrong incentives for teachers contributes to ensure that education systems in
developing countries fail at their two main tasks: giving everyone a sound basic set of skills
, and identifying talent.
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo

text: Recognizing that schools have to serve the students they do have,
rather than the ones they perhaps would like to have, may be the first
step to having a school system that gives a chance to every child
author: Abhijit V. Banerjee, Esther Duflo
